@title IERC20
 @author Paul Razvan Berg
 @notice Implementation for the ERC-20 standard.
 We have followed general OpenZeppelin guidelines: functions revert instead of returning
 `false` on failure. This behavior is nonetheless conventional and does not conflict with
 the with the expectations of ERC-20 applications.
 Additionally, an {Approval} event is emitted on calls to {transferFrom}. This allows
 applications to reconstruct the allowance for all accounts just by listening to said
 events. Other implementations of the ERC may not emit these events, as it isn't
 required by the specification.
 Finally, the non-standard {decreaseAllowance} and {increaseAllowance} functions have been
 added to mitigate the well-known issues around setting allowances.
 @dev Forked from OpenZeppelin
 https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts/blob/v3.4.0/contracts/token/ERC20/ERC20.sol

@notice Thrown when attempting to transfer more tokens than there are in the from account.
@notice Thrown when spender attempts to transfer more tokens than the owner had given them allowance for.
@notice Thrown when attempting to mint tokens to the zero address.
@notice Thrown when attempting to transfer tokens from the zero address.
@notice Thrown when the attempting to transfer tokens to the zero address.
@notice Returns the amount of tokens owned by `account`.
@notice Returns the number of decimals used to get its user representation.
@notice Returns the name of the token.
@notice Returns the symbol of the token, usually a shorter version of the name.
@notice Returns the amount of tokens in existence.

@notice Atomically decreases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.
 @dev Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.
 This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described
 in {IERC20-approve}.
 Requirements:
 - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
 - `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least `value`.
@notice Thrown when the recovered owner does not match the actual owner.
@notice Thrown when the owner is the zero address.
@notice Thrown when the permit expired.
@notice Thrown when the recovered owner is the zero address.
@notice Thrown when attempting to permit the zero address as the spender.
@notice The Eip712 domain's keccak256 hash.
@notice keccak256("Permit(address owner,address spender,uint256 value,uint256 nonce,uint256 deadline)");
@notice Provides replay protection.
@notice Eip712 version of this implementation.

@notice Sets `value` as the allowance of `spender` over `owner`'s tokens, assuming the latter's
 signed approval.
 @dev Emits an {Approval} event.
 IMPORTANT: The same issues ERC-20 `approve` has related to transaction
 ordering also apply here.
 Requirements:
 - `owner` cannot be the zero address.
 - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
 - `deadline` must be a timestamp in the future.
 - `v`, `r` and `s` must be a valid `secp256k1` signature from `owner` over the Eip712-formatted
 function arguments.
 - The signature must use `owner`'s current nonce.

@dev Returns true if `account` is a contract.
 [IMPORTANT]
 ====
 It is unsafe to assume that an address for which this function returns
 false is an externally-owned account (EOA) and not a contract.
 Among others, `isContract` will return false for the following
 types of addresses:
  - an externally-owned account
  - a contract in construction
  - an address where a contract will be created
  - an address where a contract lived, but was destroyed
 ====
 [IMPORTANT]
 ====
 You shouldn't rely on `isContract` to protect against flash loan attacks!
 Preventing calls from contracts is highly discouraged. It breaks composability, breaks support for smart wallets
 like Gnosis Safe, and does not provide security since it can be circumvented by calling from a contract
 constructor.
 ====

@dev The ETH transfer has failed.

@dev Suggested gas stipend for contract receiving ETH
 that disallows any storage writes.

@dev Sends `amount` (in wei) ETH to `to`.
 Reverts upon failure.

@dev Force sends `amount` (in wei) ETH to `to`, with a `gasStipend`.
 The `gasStipend` can be set to a low enough value to prevent
 storage writes or gas griefing.
 If sending via the normal procedure fails, force sends the ETH by
 creating a temporary contract which uses `SELFDESTRUCT` to force send the ETH.
 Reverts if the current contract has insufficient balance.

@dev Force sends `amount` (in wei) ETH to `to`, with a gas stipend
 equal to `_GAS_STIPEND_NO_GRIEF`. This gas stipend is a reasonable default
 for 99% of cases and can be overriden with the three-argument version of this
 function if necessary.
 If sending via the normal procedure fails, force sends the ETH by
 creating a temporary contract which uses `SELFDESTRUCT` to force send the ETH.
 Reverts if the current contract has insufficient balance.

@dev Sends `amount` (in wei) ETH to `to`, with a `gasStipend`.
 The `gasStipend` can be set to a low enough value to prevent
 storage writes or gas griefing.
 Simply use `gasleft()` for `gasStipend` if you don't need a gas stipend.
 Note: Does NOT revert upon failure.
 Returns whether the transfer of ETH is successful instead.

@dev Sends `amount` of ERC20 `token` from `from` to `to`.
 Reverts upon failure.
 The `from` account must have at least `amount` approved for
 the current contract to manage.

@dev Sends all of ERC20 `token` from `from` to `to`.
 Reverts upon failure.
 The `from` account must have at least `amount` approved for
 the current contract to manage.

@dev Sends `amount` of ERC20 `token` from the current contract to `to`.
 Reverts upon failure.

@dev Sends all of ERC20 `token` from the current contract to `to`.
 Reverts upon failure.

@dev Sets `amount` of ERC20 `token` for `to` to manage on behalf of the current contract.
 Reverts upon failure.

@dev Returns the amount of ERC20 `token` owned by `account`.
 Returns zero if the `token` does not exist.

@dev Provides information about the current execution context, including the
 sender of the transaction and its data. While these are generally available
 via msg.sender and msg.data, they should not be accessed in such a direct
 manner, since when dealing with meta-transactions the account sending and
 paying for execution may not be the actual sender (as far as an application
 is concerned).
 This contract is only required for intermediate, library-like contracts.

@notice Simple single owner authorization mixin.
 @author Solmate (https://github.com/transmissions11/solmate/blob/main/src/auth/Owned.sol)
@notice Emitted when there is a reentrancy call.
PRIVATE STORAGE ///

Storing an initial non-zero value makes deployment a bit more expensive but in exchange the
 refund on every call to nonReentrant will be lower in amount. Since refunds are capped to a
 percetange of the total transaction's gas, it is best to keep them low in cases like this one,
 to increase the likelihood of the full refund coming into effect.

Razvan Berg","kind":"dev","methods":{"allowance(address,address)":{"details":"This value changes when {approve} or {transferFrom} are called."},"approve(address,uint256)":{"details":"Emits an {Approval} event. IMPORTANT: Beware that changing an allowance with this method brings the risk that someone may use both the old and the new allowance by unfortunate transaction ordering. One possible solution to mitigate this race condition is to first reduce the spender's allowance to 0 and set the desired value afterwards: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/20#issuecomment-263524729 Requirements: - `spender` cannot be the zero address.","returns":{"_0":"a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded."}},"constructor":{"params":{"decimals_":"ERC-20 decimal precision of this token.","name_":"ERC-20 name of this token.","symbol_":"ERC-20 symbol of this token."}},"decreaseAllowance(address,uint256)":{"details":"Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. Requirements: - `spender` cannot be the zero address. - `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least `value`."},"increaseAllowance(address,uint256)":{"details":"Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for the problems described above. Requirements: - `spender` must not be the zero address."},"transfer(address,uint256)":{"details":"Emits a {Transfer} event. Requirements: - `to` must not be the zero address. - The caller must have a balance of at least `amount`.","returns":{"_0":"a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded."}},"transferFrom(address,address,uint256)":{"details":"Emits a {Transfer} event and an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is not required by the ERC. See the note at the beginning of {ERC-20}. Requirements: - `from` and `to` must not be the zero address. - `from` must have a balance of at least `amount`. - The caller must have approved `from` to spent at least `amount` tokens.","returns":{"_0":"a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded."}}},"stateVariables":{"_allowances":{"details":"Internal mapping of allowances."},"_balances":{"details":"Internal mapping of balances."}},"title":"ERC20","version":1},"userdoc":{"errors":{"ERC20_ApproveOwnerZeroAddress()":[{"notice":"Thrown when attempting to approve with the zero address as the owner."}],"ERC20_ApproveSpenderZeroAddress()":[{"notice":"Thrown when attempting to approve the zero address as the spender."}],"ERC20_BurnHolderZeroAddress()":[{"notice":"Thrown when attempting to burn tokens from the zero address."}],"ERC20_FromInsufficientBalance(uint256,uint256)":[{"notice":"Thrown when attempting to transfer more tokens than there are in the from account."}],"ERC20_InsufficientAllowance(address,address,uint256,uint256)":[{"notice":"Thrown when spender attempts to transfer more tokens than the owner had given them allowance for."}],"ERC20_MintBeneficiaryZeroAddress()":[{"notice":"Thrown when attempting to mint tokens to the zero address."}],"ERC20_TransferFromZeroAddress()":[{"notice":"Thrown when attempting to transfer tokens from the zero address."}],"ERC20_TransferToZeroAddress()":[{"notice":"Thrown when the attempting to transfer tokens to the zero address."}]},"events":{"Approval(address,address,uint256)":{"notice":"Emitted when an approval occurs."},"Transfer(address,address,uint256)":{"notice":"Emitted when a transfer occurs."}},"kind":"user","methods":{"allowance(address,address)":{"notice":"Returns the remaining number of tokens that `spender` will be allowed to spend on behalf of `owner` through {transferFrom}. ReentrancyGuard.metadata: {"compiler":{"version":"0.8.4+commit.c7e474f2"},"language":"Solidity","output":{"abi":[{"inputs":[],"name":"ReentrantCall","type":"error"}],"devdoc":{"author":"Paul Razvan Berg","details":"Forked from OpenZeppelin https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts/blob/v3.4.0/contracts/utils/ReentrancyGuard.sol","kind":"dev","methods":{},"title":"ReentrancyGuard","version":1},"userdoc":{"errors":{"ReentrantCall()":[{"notice":"Emitted when there is a reentrancy call."}]},"kind":"user","methods":{"constructor":{"notice":"Storing an initial non-zero value makes deployment a bit more expensive but in exchange the refund on every call to nonReentrant will be lower in amount. Since refunds are capped to a percetange of the total transaction's gas, it is best to keep them low in cases like this one, to increase the likelihood of the full refund coming into effect."}},"notice":"Contract module that helps prevent reentrant calls to a function. Inheriting from `ReentrancyGuard` will make the {nonReentrant} modifier available, which can be applied to functions to make sure there are no nested (reentrant) calls to them. Note that because there is a single `nonReentrant` guard, functions marked as `nonReentrant` may not call one another. This can be worked around by making those functions `private`, and then adding `external` `nonReentrant` entry points to them.","version":1}},"settings":{"compilationTarget":{"contracts/utils/ReentrancyGuard.sol":"ReentrancyGuard"},"evmVersion":"istanbul","libraries":{},"metadata":{"bytecodeHash":"ipfs"},"optimizer":{"enabled":true,"runs":400},"remappings":[]},"sources":{"contracts/utils/ReentrancyGuard.sol":{"keccak256":"0x6d547b6e5f21de3600bb984e6debd895bad2b3dfa5bb61daf75cc7798034d822","license":"Unlicense","urls":["bzz-raw://d8d5d7a24752cfa7426d8f908f1e56998a2771d437435bf189eb2784b0f126f2","dweb:/ipfs/QmNfonELxViXFDGvjkNsFz8hES2ahij157JNHGcVejdzjV"]}},"version":1}
